Input.threadtitle: Prisons as Organizations?
Input.posts:
Can we envisage prisons as organizations? Would it help in achieving the goals of criminal law i.e reform or revenge or rehabilitation? Tihar Jail in New Delhi, India can be the subject of a case study. Please visit its website here http://tihartj.nic.in/tihar_jail.asp
Upvotes:
3
By 'prisons' you mean the institution that runs the facilities where convicted persons are incarcerated - Yes, they are organizations, with the goal of securing and managing the prison facility, participated in by prison guards or wardens who are organized in a hierarchy (the social structure) and who have the skills and S.O.P.'s (technology) for dealing with the inmates. The prisoners are definitely stakeholders... but as a group of prisoners, they do not necessarily consist an organization. They are a group of people thrown together into a prison facility due to their conviction. It is possible that prisoners in a facility decide to organize themselves into a prison association. If they do so, and they meet the definition of an organization particularly the four elements, then a prison can be an organization of prisoners.

Input.threadtitle: Embrace a combination of rational and open systems and harness natural systems?
Input.posts:
Ideally an organisation is a combination of a rational and an open system. A company will definitely prefer a rational structure within the organisation, while its 'brain' is subject to its environment and always making decisions that adapt best to exterior factors. However any organisation is inevitably a natural system by nature. The directors may make mistakes. Board members may have different perspectives to the same issue. Everybody naturally wants their own benefits maximised, through they might have a common goal of making the company continually grow. Generally, the characteristics of a natural system are what an organisation wants to conquer against. But is there a possibility any of the natural system characteristics is positively utilised to enhance the performance of an organisation? One simple example may be encouraging benign competition between members at a single level. But I am really interested in possibly more advanced manners. I appreciate it if you could leave your idea here. Thanks.
Upvotes:
3
One particular book I have read comes to mind: http://www.amazon.com/The-Organizational-Sweet-Spot-Innovative/dp/0387981934 The author does a good job of discussing how employees become disengaged with their work when their personal goals stray too far from being aligned with the overall organization's goals. Informal networks will form between groups of individuals that are focused on alternative ideas and interests (sometimes completely unrelated to the context of the organization). I think it is rather common for organizations (especially schools and businesses) to take a very rational, top-down approach to solving this issue and try to force employees to stay on task. They try to divide employees into functions, and question productivity when employees begin meddling in non-business-issues. However, the author argues that attempting to suppress informal networks and their activities can be very detrimental to the organization. There is benefit in diversity of thought, and it is these very interactions that lead to meaningful relationships among workers. He further argues that informal networks are impossible to eradicate, as they are an emergent phenomenon (that is, these informal groups form on their own and if they are forced to disperse, they will likely re-emerge). Informal networks tend to oppose the normative and even cultural structures within an organization, especially if these are formally imposed. The author suggests that organizational leaders should try to develop a shared context in which those operating in the formal structure and those in the informal networks can work together. Here is Amazon.com's description: 'Employee disengagement is one of the most pressing problems plaguing managers today hampering the innovation capacities of countless organizations. According to recent polls, some 20 percent of workers report feeling disconnected from their jobs, in an environment of stagnating wages, massive layoffs, rising health care costs, and other factors that contribute to alienation, distrust, and apathy. In The Organizational Sweet Spot , Dr. Charles Ehin takes a refreshing new look at what it will take to reengage disaffected workers and boost their resolve to advance novel ideas. Applying the latest research from such fields as evolutionary psychology, social neuroscience, organizational behavior, anthropology, and social network analysis, Ehin demonstrates how employee disengagement is rooted in a fundamental misalignment between people’s instinctive drive to develop their personal and group identities through informal or “emergent” relationships and the ways in which organizational goals and profit motives are executed through formal bureaucracy. The challenge for today’s organizations—which operate under constantly changing conditions—is to narrow this gap, that is, to find the “sweet spot”, where the formal and informal elements of the organization overlap. Ehin provides practical tools for leaders to support this “shared access domain” to improve productivity, catalyze innovation, and inspire exceptional performance. His new model is likely to reverberate throughout current management thinking as we move toward creating more vital and meaningful workplaces.'

One example for 'Participants'. -you can hire a good mix of 'discovering driven'/'delivery driven' employees -you can train employees to question more, to associate ideas, to design more effectively, to network more, etc... -you can collaborate and network within an ecosystem to gain knowledge -etc... I'd be curious to hear your various idea !

One example for 'Participants'. -you can hire a good mix of 'discovering driven'/'delivery driven' employees -you can train employees to question more, to associate ideas, to design more effectively, to network more, etc... -you can collaborate and network within an ecosystem to gain knowledge -etc... Input.threadtitle: How can we shape an organization to make it more innovative ?
Input.posts:
This question is a central one for firms whose long term growth value, competitive advantage and business model depend on the ability to 'innovate'. First of all, I define innovation as 'the embodiment of an insightful and effective idea into a market place'. The idea is to create value, to deliver value and obviously to capture value (I'm talking from the firm point of view not NGOs). So as I understand for the moment, the various facets of an organization are: -social structures -participants -shared goals -technology and tasks -environment Within this framework how do you build the most innovative firm? One example for 'Participants'. -you can hire a good mix of 'discovering driven'/'delivery driven' employees -you can train employees to question more, to associate ideas, to design more effectively, to network more, etc... -you can collaborate and network within an ecosystem to gain knowledge -etc... I'd be curious to hear your various idea !

Thanks a lot for those ideas. Innovation is a complex process involving an iteraction of subelements such as 'Technology' (id est the value proposition), 'Implementation' (how to make this value proposition real, to deliver it) and 'Market ( to who are we delivering? how much value can we capture?). This intricated iteraction evolves in a stage gate model Search-->Select-->Implement-->Capture While your ideas are certainly very good ones for the 'Search'/'Select' stages, in my experience they are not very efficient in the 'implement'/'capture' ones. The problem is that a good 'innovation' driven organization should be an evolving one adapted to the current stage of the innovation in research inside. 'Search' Social structure: free cross functionnal project team, bureaucratic less flat organization, open boundaries organization, free organization with a kind of 'artistic entropy', totally informal network based of experience and knowledge Environment: innovation ecosystems/ private R&D public research partnership Goals: finding a set of 'suitable' ideas (value creating for both the customers and the firm) Participants:'discovery driven' creative knowledge workers Technologies: questionning, networking with ICT, scanning the knowledge/concepts environment, associating ideas 'Select' Social structure: constrained committee of cross functionnal experts, more controled system with less entropy Environment: integration of the 'innovative projects' into the wider firm global organization Goals: selecting the best ideas in coherence with the firm strategy, business models and customers future needs Participants: experienced industry experts half 'discovery'/half 'delivery' driven Technologies: lean management, quick and cheap experimenting, 'Implement' Social structure: very constrained system, very bureaucratic and hierarchical driven, hard control on process and quality Environment: supply chain, firm direct boundaries Goals: create in real the value proposition and deliver it the most cost effectively Participants: rational 'operations engineer' like talent, data/analytics driven scientifc guys Technologies: supply chain management, operation management, industrial engineering, optimization 'Capture' Social structure: closers to the general top management, formal structure with decision making based on personnal experience and leaders intuition Environment: the customer world id est the target market Goals: deliver the value at the right price to the right people through the right channel at the right place Participants: salesmen and marketers Technologies: customer relationship management, experience driven marketing, solution sales, etc... The problem is that those 'suborganizations' are running neither in serial nor in parallel but they still influence each other. Hard problem isn't it ? :)

While I agree that there is obviously a part of luck (a bad managed project can have a superb outcome while a very effectively managed project can lead to a dead end depending on how the external environment evolves), I tend to believe that 'innovation' can somehow be a bit controlled. As you rightfully mentionned, there are dozens of definition of innovation and the organization as to create its own in coherence with its long term strategic vision. A funny fact for example is to see the difference between venture capitalists who fund start ups and corporate R&D division investing in their own big firm. VC understood that investing as to be made in several stages (with increasing amount as the uncertainty decreases) and investing in a basket of very various start ups (corporate R&D somehow forgot the concept of diversification). Concerning how to increase the innovation power of an organization (id explore new ideas and exploit succesfull ones), you need to have a deep interconnection between the various departements: -general top management: senior leaders and executives to define the definition of what innovation should be -marketing: to identify the 'job to be done' that customers are expecting and to identify the potential future customers which are not currently engaged in the market -HR: to hire top talent (well balanced 'discovery/delivery' driven), to develop them (many firms forget that point) and to define smart rewards and incentives -finance: to fund and invest in a project portfolio balanced in term of risk/return as a VC invests in start ups -project manager: to make the various project moving forward on time, on quality and on costs etc... Innovation is an organization wide topic and for example I really like the example you gave 'failure is an option but fear is not' type organization. The real problem is the 'Exploit the present while exploring the future and forgetting the past' organization balance.

A lot of interesting posts ! According to Scott D Anthony (Managing director of Innosight, a leading innovation consulting firm created by HBS Clayton Christensen), a good innovative organization is a growth factory with: I) A clear growth blueprint: -well defined growth type -shared growth goals and guidelines II) An 'innovation' production system: -robust innovation processes (innovation is not treated randomly) -idea supply chain (here the knowledge management) -new growth group (could be in a semi external venture) -little bets labs (cheap experiments to test business concepts) -M&A and partnership engines (you can't innovate alone anymore) III) Governance and controls: -idea governance systems (the select stage) -portfolio tracking systems -resource allocation systems -continuous improvement system (or innovating the way we innovate) IV) Leadership, talent and culture: -lean forward leaders (without 'innovation driven executive' a firm can't innovate) -innovation talent as human capital -measurement and reward systems -development programs What do you think? Anything to be added?

Input.threadtitle: Does Gender Play a Role in the Success of Organizations?
Input.posts:
In various organizations there are terms like 'Good ol' Boys' and the like. I know that the environment of an organization can be vastly different based on the gender of the leader or associates. It has been my experience for instance that organizations that employ more women have more emotional conflict, office politics, gossip but often validate accomplishment more. Conversely organizations that employ more men have more harassment, and less verbal validation. Do you think that there is a difference in production outputs between men and women. That organizational environments are better with more men, or more women?
